awd_titl_txt: TRIPODS+X: EDU: Collaborative Research: Investigations of Student Difficulties in Data Science Instruction
awd_abstract_narration:
Web-browsing histories, online newspapers, streaming music, and stock prices all show that we live in an age of data. Extracting meaning from data is necessary in many fields to comprehend the information flow. This need has fueled rapid growth in data science education aiming to serve the next generation of policy makers, data science researchers, and global citizens. Initially, teaching practices have been drawn from data science's parent disciplines (e.g., computer science and mathematics). This project begins the process of investigating data science education as its own field of research. It aims to identify preconceptions students may have when they first enter a data science classroom, and what other courses from related programs are shaping their preconceptions.

This project conducts a mixed-method educational investigation to collect data and documentation of conceptual misunderstandings and difficulties in data science. This investigation will (1) identify classes in a variety of disciplines currently teaching the critical topics identified in the National Academy of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine (NASEM) Report: Data Science for Undergraduates: Opportunities and Options; (2) work with instructors of those courses to gather evidence of student thinking (especially misconceptions) surrounding those topics; and (3) survey early career data science practitioners to assess those misconceptions that persist to employment. During this educational investigation, we will gather student work as those students are first engaging with data science concepts as well as the teaching materials used in those courses. Additional research methodologies include student interviews and surveys. Item (3), working directly with data science practitioners, will assist in identifying cutting-edge technical topics and oversights by instructors that might be otherwise missed, based on current workforce demands.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This TRIPODS+X grant sought to understand the conceptual misunderstandings and challenges that arise when teaching data science. We had three objectives that each centered on a different stakeholder. First, in our student-centered objective, we sought to identify student misconceptions about data science topics, as they happened during a semester of instruction. Second in our across-curricular objective, we worked to identify where data science ideas are being taught (including courses and departments labeled “data science” as well as those beyond those “typical” spaces). Finally in our defining-data-science objective, we identified some disconnects regarding the core elements of data science as defined in (academic) curricula and in (industrial) jobs. 

Over the last four years, we have had the following outcomes as related to our three objectives. For our student-centered objective, we have created, deployed, revised, and redeployed a crowd-sourced difficulty protocol. For our across-curricular objective, we worked to develop a tool that can identify potential courses that contain topics of interest. For our defining-data-science objective, we created, deployed, and analyzed a survey for both data science instructors and practitioners to take about what defines data science and what concepts are important for a first course in data science as well as completed a deep literature analysis.

The public outcomes generated for this project include one peer reviewed article, and several public talks at national conferences and local venues. Other outcomes include a code repository for our course-identification tool and posters about said tool. Work in this area is ongoing both by this team and other researchers. Two additional manuscripts are also pending submission.
